Chapter.Section: An important note The operations, methods, properties, and functions described in this manual only apply to semigroups of transformations, partial permutations, and subsemigroups of regular Rees 0-matrix semigroups over groups. For the sake of brevity, we have opted to say semigroup rather than semigroup of transformations, partial permutations, and subsemigroups of regular Rees 0-matrix semigroups over groups.

Introduction This is the manual for the &Semigroups; package version &VERSION;. &Semigroups; &VERSION; is an updated and expanded version of the
http://schmidt.nuigalway.ie/monoid/index.html by Goetz Pfeiffer, Steve A. Linton, Edmund F. Robertson, and Nik Ruskuc and the http://www-history.mcs.st-and.ac.uk/~jamesm/monoid/index.html by J. D. Mitchell.
Some of the theory behind the algorithms in &Semigroups; is described in and described in . Another reference is . A reference for free inverse semigroups is Section 5.10 in . The functions for: finding a smaller degree partial permutation representation of an inverse semigroup are based on ; and finding the maximal subsemigroups of a Rees matrix or 0-matrix semigroup are based on Remark 1 in .
&Semigroups; &VERSION; retains all the functionality of the original &Monoid; for &GAP; 3; and those functions from &Monoid; 3.1.4 not involved in the computation of automorphism groups of semigroups.
&noindent; &Semigroups; &VERSION; contains more efficient methods than those available in the &GAP; library (and in many cases more efficient than any other software) for creating semigroups, calculating their Green's classes, size, elements, group of units, minimal ideal, and testing membership, finding the inverses of a regular element, and factorizing elements over the generators, and many more; see Chapters and . There are also methods for testing if a semigroup satisfies a particular property, such as if it is regular, simple, inverse, completely regular, and a variety of further properties; see Chapter . Several standard examples of semigroups are provided see Section . &Semigroups; also provides abbreviated names for some of the commonly used &GAP; library functions related to semigroups, and functions to read and write collections of transformations or partial permutations to a file; see and .
There are also functions in &Semigroups; to define and manipulate free inverse semigroups and their elements; this part of the package was written by Julius Jonušas.
&noindent; The &Semigroups; package is written &GAP; code and requires the &Orb; and &IO;packages. The &Orb; package is used to efficiently compute components of actions, which underpin many of the features of &Semigroups;. The &IO; package is used to read and write transformations and partial permutations to a file. The &Grape; package is used in the functions and but nowhere else in &Semigroups;. If &Grape; is not available, then &Semigroups; can be used as normal with the exception that and will not work.
&Semigroups; is still under development, and so some features may not function as expected. At the present time, I do not know of any errors or serious issues with &Semigroups;. If you find a bug or an issue with the package, then please let me know by emailing me the details at: jdm3@st-and.ac.uk.

Installing the &Semigroups; package
In this section we give a brief description of how to start using &Semigroups;. If you have any problems getting &Semigroups; working, then you could try emailing me at jdm3@st-and.ac.uk.
It is assumed that you have a working copy of &GAP; with version number &GAPVERS; or higher. The most up-to-date version of &GAP; and instructions on how to install it can be obtained from the main &GAP; webpage &vspace;
&noindent;&vspace; http://www.gap-system.org
&noindent; The following is a summary of the steps that should lead to a successful installation of &Semigroups;:
ensure that the &IO; package version &IOVERS; or higher is available. For more details go to:&vspace;
&noindent; http://www-groups.mcs.st-and.ac.uk/~neunhoef/Computer/Software/Gap/ io.html
ensure that the &Orb; package version &ORBVERS; or higher is available. For more details go to: &vspace;
&noindent; http://www-groups.mcs.st-and.ac.uk/~neunhoef/Computer/Software/Gap/orb.html
&noindent; Note that &Orb; and &Semigroups; both perform better if &Orb; is compiled.
if you want to be able to calculate the Munn semigroup of a semilattice or the maximal subsemigroups of a Rees 0-matrix semigroup, then make sure that the &Grape; package version &GRAPEVERS; or higher is available. For more details go to:&vspace;
&noindent; http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~leonard/grape/
If &Grape; is not fully installed, then &Semigroups; can be used as normal with the exception that will not work. The method for will work provided &Grape; can be loaded, i.e. it is not necessary for &Grape; to be compiled.

Use &R;-classes not &L;-classes It is harder for &Semigroups; to compute Green's &L;- and &H;-classes of a transformation semigroup and the methods used to compute with Green's &R;- and &D;-classes are the most efficient in &Semigroups;. Thus, if you are computing with a transformation semigroup, wherever possible it is advisable to use the commands relating to Green's &R;- or &D;-classes rather than those relating to Green's &L;- or &H;-classes. No such difficulties are present when computing with semigroups of partial permutations, or subsemigroups of a regular Rees 0-matrix semigroup over a group.
The methods in &Semigroups; allow the computation of individual Green's classes without the need to compute all the elements of the underlying semigroup; see . It is also possible to compute all the &R;-classes, the number of elements and test membership in a semigroup without computing all the elements; see, for example, , , , , or . This may be useful if you want to study a very large semigroup where computing all the elements of the semigroup is not feasible.

New methods for existing functions &Semigroups; contains functions synonymous to some of those define in the &GAP; library but, for the sake of convenience, they have abbreviated names; further details can be found at the appropriate points in the later chapters of the manual.
&Semigroups; contains different methods for some &GAP; library functions, and so you might notice that &GAP; behaves differently when &Semigroups; is loaded. For more details about semigroups in &GAP; or Green's relations in particular, see or .
